Question: What are enzymes, substrate, and product?
Explanation: Enzymes are proteins that act as catalysts (make it easier for chemical reactions to occur). Substrates are molecules that bind to an enzyme. For any given enzyme, one or more specific substrate molecules will bind to that enzyme. Substrates are then converted to product(s) by the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme.
Input: Metabolic pathways consist of an ordered set of chemical reactions that are catalyzed by enzymes. At the heart of metabolism are enzymes. These proteins embrace substrates, quickly generating products. One or more substrates bind to an enzyme‚Äö√Ñ√¥s active site. As a result, the activation energy is reduced and the reaction proceeds much more quickly than it otherwise would. Without enzymes, metabolism would grind to a halt. Furthermore, the structural characteristics of enzymes allow the regulation of their function, thus allowing the regulation of the metabolic pathways they participate in.

Question: Describe an example of interdependence among cells within your body.

Question: Scientists turn to model organisms ‚Äî species that are easy to keep in the lab and have been studied extensively ‚Äî and use them as study subjects. Rats and mice, for example, are key to medical research. How could research on mice or rats help answer our medical research questions ‚Äî questions that are, after all, about humans?
Explanation: We can test out medicines, for example, by giving them to diabetic mice. Or we can figure out what causes a health problem by doing experiments on mice that wouldn‚Äôt be possible with people. Such research is useful because mice and people are related by ancestry. We have similar organs, cells, and molecules. Something we learn in mice might apply directly to people, or it might at least point us in the right direction for further study. To learn more: Genetic Science Learning Center

Dozens of mouse and rat strains have been specifically maintained as research subjects because they reliably develop problems like obesity, diabetes, or behavioral disorders such as addiction. How could research on mice or rats help answer our medical research questions ‚Äî questions that are, after all, about humans?
Explanation: We can test out medicines, for example, by giving them to diabetic mice. Dozens of mouse and rat strains have been specifically maintained as research subjects because they reliably develop problems like obesity, diabetes, or behavioral disorders such as addiction. How could research on mice or rats help answer our medical research questions ‚Äî questions that are, after all, about humans?
Explanation: We can test out medicines, for example, by giving them to diabetic mice. Or we can figure out what causes a health problem by doing experiments on mice that wouldn‚Äôt be possible with people. Such research is useful because mice and people are related by ancestry. We have similar organs, cells, and molecules. Something we learn in mice might apply directly to people, or it might at least point us in the right direction for further study. To learn more: Genetic Science Learning Center

Question: Bill, an overweight man in his twenties, goes on a very low calorie diet. He is determined to lose weight and keep it off. Within a few days, Bill has already lost four pounds! How or why was Bill able to lose those first few pounds so quickly?
Explanation: Most of the weight lost was probably water weight. Bill catabolized his glycogen and the resulting water was excreted in the urine.

Question: In addition to chlorophyll, plants produce other pigments. Some of them act as ‚Äúhelpers‚Äù to chlorophyll: they absorb different wavelengths of light and pass some of the energy to chlorophyll.
